title: 'I live with 3 different voices chatting away in my head
text:

Halfway through my Drama & Theatre Studies exam, when I was 18, I heard a man whisper ‘Boom’.

Shocked, I looked at the invigilators, wondering what they were talking about.

But as I turned my page to read the next question I heard it again.

‘Boom.’

I spun around to look at my fellow students, who had their heads bowed over their papers, as the word was repeated over and over again, sometimes quietly, sometimes shouted loudly.

Not one single student reacted and it dawned on me the voice was inside my head.

I forced myself to concentrate on the rest of the exam and gradually the noise subsided.

Afterwards, as my classmates chatted and hugged, I quickly said my goodbyes and jumped into my mum’s car, terrified and close to tears, but I didn’t say anything to my mum.

That night as I lay in bed the voice started again, making random sounds or shouting one-syllable words.

As I squeezed my eyes closed, desperately trying to get rid of the noise, an older man’s voice would shout ‘good’, ‘boom’ or even ‘rain’ and ‘snow’.

Exam stress meant I hadn’t been sleeping, so I put it down to that, coupled with the depression and anxiety I’d been diagnosed with a year earlier.

But every night, as I tried to sleep, the noises returned.

(Image: Getty Images)

Then two weeks later a second voice, this time female, joined in and they took turns to say random one-syllable words.

I’d lie awake, trying to ignore them, but my heart would be pumping. Every day I felt strung out and I quickly spiralled into a deep depression.

Two weeks later, as my mum Gillian and I sat in the car together, I broke down.

‘I’m hearing voices in my head,’ I blurted out through my tears.

She arranged for me to have an emergency mental health assessment.

Three doctors assessed me and came to the conclusion the voices were a consequence of depression and anxiety, so I was prescribed anti-depressants.

One doctor told me it’s common for healthy adults to hear voices in times of stress, which was reassuring.

Taking the medication helped my anxiety and depression, but still the voices would come back, usually at night.

By then they were saying full sentences and chatting together.

Other times they’d make basic statements like ‘I really like apples’.

And within months a third voice joined in, this time a male around the same age as me.

(Image: Supplied)

I soon noticed they had three distinct personalities, and even heard their names.

The older man was called Eros and was definitely the ringleader.

His was the voice I’d hear most often, and he loved to talk about himself in an egotistical way.

Terry was the younger man, who tended to chat about college and high school, while Psyche, the female, was the kindest and often asked me about my day.

That said, they could all be malicious, and when I was anxious they’d enjoy playing on my fears.

If I was on my way to university in Liverpool, where I was studying Creative Writing, they’d insist the train was going to be late, or if I was just stressed they’d agree something bad was about to happen.

The lower I felt, the more they’d tell me I was fat and ugly, and over time my self-esteem plummeted.

I knew the voices were a manifestation of my own brain, but hearing over and over again how worthless I was Ieft me believing it.

I went back and forwards to doctors, but they were convinced it was due to depression and anxiety, and I felt reluctant to push for anything more.

I know hearing voices can be symptoms of psychosis or schizophrenia, but sometimes it can be nothing to do with mental illness at all.

By the Christmas of my second year at university, it had all got too much to bear.

I was still living at home, but I’d withdrawn from my family.

Eventually I felt the only way out was to kill myself.

On 23 December I tried to write a suicide note but I couldn’t concentrate, so to distract myself I scrolled through music videos on YouTube.

I found myself enjoying Korean pop music and discovered that when

I was listening to it the voices stopped, possibly because I was concentrating on another language.

Relieved, I listened to it all night, and the following day I confided in my mum about how low I’d got.

She was incredibly supportive and together we worked out strategies to cope with my anxiety.

When I went back to university after the New Year I decided to try a new approach and befriend the voices.

It seemed to work, and now they are less malevolent and sometimes include me.

Other times I can hear them chatting about politics or Brexit ; information I’ve absorbed through the day.

However when I need some peace, drowning them out with Korean pop seems to work.

I also find if I ignore them they will eventually quieten down.

Now they tend to only start up at night, unless I’m stressed in which case they can materialise at any time and make me jump because I wasn’t expecting them.

They still are evil occasionally, but most of the time we rub along pretty well together.

Telling my friends was terrifying, as I thought it would change how they felt about me, but they’ve all reacted brilliantly.

It hasn’t had a negative impact on any friendships – and I hope in the future the voices won’t stand in the way of me having a relationship either.

At university, as part of my degree, we had to produce the first chapter of a science fiction novel, and I decided to incorporate my own experiences into my story.

(Image: Supplied)

I started a tale called Nightmare Scenario set in 2047, where everyone has to wear a watch that tracks their every move.

The main character has voices in her head that force her to play a dangerous game by threatening to hurt her or others if she refuses.

I found writing it cathartic, and felt if people were prepared to believe in this dystopian world they might also be more accepting and understanding of those who hear voices in their head.

Once I began to write, the words poured out of me, and within a month I’d finished my first draft.

I was stunned and thrilled when a publisher agreed to produce my novel and now I can’t wait until it hits the shelves this month.

It’s hard to talk about hearing voices because of the stigma, but it’s important to be open about mental health.

Illnesses like psychosis and schizophrenia only make the news when the voices inside someone’s head have urged them to hurt someone or harm themselves.

Mine have never done either of those things, and I think it’s important people know there’s another side to the condition.

Of course I hope one day Eros, Terry and Psyche will fade away, but for now I’m managing to live alongside them, and I know they don’t define who I am or what I can achieve.

I’m studying for a PhD and I hope to write more books in the Scenario series.

I’ve learnt to accept there’s much more to me than just the voices in my head.

Hearing Voices: The Facts

Hearing voices is an auditory hallucination that may or may not be associated with mental illness.

It’s the most common type of hallucination in people with psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia, but a large number of otherwise healthy individuals have also reported hearing them.

According to the Mental Health Foundation, between 5% and 28% of the population hears voices that other people do not.

The voices can be critical, complimentary or neutral, and may make potentially harmful commands or engage the person in conversation.

They may give a running commentary of the person’s actions.

Traumatic experiences, such as abuse, bereavement or neglect, are considered to be among the most significant triggers of auditory hallucinations, particularly among children.

In one study, up to 70% of participants reported that hearing voices started after a significant traumatic or emotional event.
